title: Quotation of the Day: Democrats Also Seek Criminal Inquiries
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 10, 2021.
content: “People who think that the way forward is to brush this under the rug seem to have missed the fact that there is a ticking time bomb under the rug.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Nancy Bush Ellis, Sister and Aunt of Presidents, Dies at 94
description: Unlike most of her family, she was a liberal Democrat for a time, supporting the NAACP Legal Defense Fund and environmental causes.
content: Nancy Bush Ellis, the sister of one president and aunt of another, who for a time devoted herself to Democratic causes despite her family dynasty’s Republican lineage, died on Sunday at an assisted living facility in Concord, Mass. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘All Creatures Great and Small’ Rehabilitates Cows and Soothes Souls
description: This charming mini-series adaptation of the James Herriot novel was a surprise pandemic hit in Britain. This week it arrives in an America in need of its own relief.
content: A young veterinary surgeon begins to practice in the remote Yorkshire Dales in 1937, treating abscesses in horses’ hooves and milk fever in cows and prescribing diets for overfed lap dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: At Least 4 Dead in Shooting Spree in Chicago and Evanston
description: A rampage that started in Chicago and ended in nearby Evanston left at least four people dead, including the suspect. At least four others were critically wounded.
content: A deadly shooting spree on Saturday that started in Chicago and ended in a shootout in nearby Evanston, Ill., left at least four people dead, including the suspected gunman, and at least four others critically wounded, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Entrepreneurs Bet Big on Immersive Art Despite Covid-19
description: For-profit experiential art centers are investing hundreds of millions of dollars in a business where audiences have evaporated because of the pandemic.
content: Even as the pandemic takes its toll on tourism, immersive museums and experiential art centers are expanding to new cities and wooing investors willing to gamble on the future of the emerging industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: With ‘I Hate Men,’ a French Feminist Touches a Nerve
description: Pauline Harmange is adjusting to the success and backlash of her debut book, one of a handful of titles from France that suggest a more frank approach to sexism and gender violence.
content: PARIS — If it hadn’t been for a man, Pauline Harmange’s literary debut, “I Hate Men,” might have gone unnoticed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesia Crash Thwarts Push to Rehabilitate Country’s Airlines
description: The loss of Sriwijaya Air Flight 182 on Saturday was a grim start to the year in a sprawling archipelago nation where barely a year goes by without an air disaster.
content: [Read our What We Know on the Indonesian plane crash.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Prosecutors mull charges for theft of national security information after laptops and documents are stolen in Capitol siege.
description: Michael R. Sherwin, the U.S. attorney in Washington, said on Sunday that the Justice Department was considering charges for “theft of national security information” after the violent mob that stormed the Capitol on Wednesday looted laptops, documents and other items from congressional offices.
content: Michael R. Sherwin, the U.S. attorney in Washington, said on Sunday that the Justice Department was considering charges for “theft of national security information” after the violent mob that stormed the Capitol on Wednesday looted laptops, documents and other items from congressional offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Lawmakers may have been exposed to the coronavirus while sheltering during the Capitol riot, a doctor says.
description: While sheltering in a secure location as a mob of Trump supporters stormed the Capitol on Wednesday, House lawmakers may have been exposed to someone who was infected with the coronavirus, Congress’s Office of the Attending Physician said on Sunday.
content: While sheltering in a secure location as a mob of Trump supporters stormed the Capitol on Wednesday, House lawmakers may have been exposed to someone who was infected with the coronavirus, Congress’s Office of the Attending Physician said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: After refusing to do so, Trump orders flags to be flown at half-staff.
description: President Trump on Sunday issued a proclamation ordering that the American flag at the White House and at all federal buildings and grounds be lowered in honor of two U.S. Capitol police officers who died after the violent riot by the president’s supporters at the Capitol on Wednesday.
content: President Trump on Sunday issued a proclamation ordering that the American flag at the White House and at all federal buildings and grounds be lowered in honor of two U.S. Capitol police officers who died after the violent riot by the president’s supporters at the Capitol on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A vote on impeaching Trump could come this week.
content: Momentum for impeaching President Trump a second time was growing rapidly over the weekend among Democrats and some Republicans, angry over Mr. Trump’s role in the assault on the Capitol building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: True Stories of Hooking Up During Covid-19
description: New world. New rules. Same old problems.
content: It took Alison Stevenson eight months to find a pandemic friend with benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington and Ken Belson
title: Here’s What Happened in Sunday’s N.F.L. Wild-Card Games
description: The Browns stormed past the Steelers, the heavily-favored Saints got a businesslike win over the Bears and Lamar Jackson finally won his first playoff game.
content: The Cleveland Browns hadn’t been to the playoffs in 17 seasons, but it took them just one game to notch their first playoff victory in a quarter century as they held off the rival Pittsburgh Steelers, 48-37.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Texas City Settles Mayor’s Race by Pulling Ping-Pong Balls From a Top Hat
description: The random drawing came after a December runoff ended with 1,010 votes each for the two candidates running for mayor of Dickinson, a Houston suburb.
content: There were no lawsuits, no cries of election fraud and certainly no angry mobs storming the seat of government. Instead, a tie between two candidates running for mayor of a Houston suburb was settled after their names were drawn from a top hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Eric Adelson and Kate Kelly
title: ‘It Became Sort of Lawless’: Florida Vaccine Rollout Turns Into a Free-for-All
description: Florida decided people 65 and older should get the coronavirus vaccine first. But demand has overwhelmed supply, and people are frustrated.
content: MIAMI — Linda Kleindienst Bruns registered for a coronavirus vaccine in late December, on the first day the health department in Tallahassee, Fla., opened for applications for people her age. Despite being 72, with her immune system suppressed by medication that keeps her breast cancer in remission, she spent days waiting to hear back about an appointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Emma Grillo
title: Hang Out With Clouded Leopards and Watch ‘Another Round’
description: This week, learn about the basics of perfume, listen to a string quartet or catch Regina King’s directorial debut.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: With Trump Presidency Winding Down, Push for Assange Pardon Ramps Up
description: Supporters of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange have enlisted a lobbyist with connections to the president and filed a clemency petition with the White House.
content: WASHINGTON — Allies of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange have ramped up a push for a last-minute pardon from President Trump, enlisting a lobbyist with connections to the administration, trying to rally supporters across the political spectrum and filing a clemency petition with the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dore and Sam Von Ehren
title: Solve a Nonogram (a What?)
description: It’s a logic puzzle that uses numbers, and if that’s not hard enough, we’ve added a crossword twist.  Happy New Year!
content: Nonograms are deceptively simple logic puzzles: You use digits to create a pattern of filled-in squares in the empty grid provided.  Each number on the lines outside the grid represents a block of squares to be blacked out in that row or column (see 1 Across). Once all the correct squares are filled in, a picture emerges. This nonogram adds crossword-inspired clues to make things even more interesting. The answers are numbers that you write into the spaces provided, which then help you find the date-appropriate image.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 10, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 10, 2021.
content: An article on Page 9 about the Royal Academy of Dance misstates in several instances the surname of the archives and records manager at the academy. She is Eleanor Fitzpatrick, not Fitzgerald.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Morgan
title: Got a Box? Make a Museum
description: Right now, tactile learning in school is difficult, but exploring a passion at home can fill the void.
content: The main thing to know about Ingrid Abbott, 11, a fifth grader in the modest mountain town of Orem, Utah, is that she is really into butterflies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: In a viral video, Schwarzenegger links the Capitol riot to a rampage that was a prelude to the Holocaust.
description: In a video posted to Twitter on Sunday that quickly drew millions of views, Arnold Schwarzenegger, the movie star and former California governor, compared the riot at the Capitol last week to Kristallnacht, a rampage in Germany in 1938 in which Nazi-inspired mobs burned synagogues and destroyed Jewish-owned shops.
content: In a video posted to Twitter on Sunday that quickly drew millions of views, Arnold Schwarzenegger, the movie star and former California governor, compared the riot at the Capitol last week to Kristallnacht, a rampage in Germany in 1938 in which Nazi-inspired mobs burned synagogues and destroyed Jewish-owned shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Strong Views and ‘Close to the Boss’: How U.S. Envoy Reshaped a Conflict
description: David Friedman, President Trump’s bankruptcy lawyer-turned-ambassador, leaves his post having radically overhauled policy toward Israel and the Palestinians.
content: JERUSALEM — Love him or hate him, and most people who have paid attention fall into one camp or the other, Ambassador David M. Friedman will complete his tour of duty in Israel this month having etched his name in history as one of America’s most influential envoys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Chance for a Hit
description: Martha Kimes feeds our souls.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Are you hungry? I’m hungry. What we need is a snack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: The U.S. vaccine rollout needs to ‘hit the reset,’ an ex-F.D.A. chief says.
description: Warning that vaccines are the only backstop the country has against fast-spreading new variants of the coronavirus, Dr. Scott Gottlieb, the former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said Sunday that federal and state leaders need to “hit the reset and adopt a new strategy” to get far more shots into arms as soon as possible.
content: Warning that vaccines are the only backstop the country has against fast-spreading new variants of the coronavirus, Dr. Scott Gottlieb, the former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said Sunday that federal and state leaders need to “hit the reset and adopt a new strategy” to get far more shots into arms as soon as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: The 51st State? Washington Revisits an Uphill Cause With New Fervor
description: District of Columbia statehood has long been out of reach. Proponents hope Democratic control of the federal government and the security issues raised over the past week could change that.
content: WASHINGTON — On the day after a mob rampaged through the halls of Congress, the mayor of Washington, D.C., Muriel E. Bowser, heaped praise on the Metropolitan Police Department officers who had rushed to restore order after the Capitol’s police force was overwhelmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Amy Qin
title: State Dept. Moves to Ease Restrictions on Meeting With Taiwan Officials
description: The decision by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is meant to signal a warming of relations with Taipei and a tougher line with Beijing, but the Biden administration could easily reverse the move.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States said on Saturday that it would relax its restrictions on interactions between American officials and their counterparts in Taiwan as the Trump administration seeks to lock in a tougher line against Beijing in its final days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
title: Despite Chaos and Big Losses, Republicans Still Control Most of Georgia
description: Democrats had huge breakthroughs in winning the presidential vote and two Senate runoff elections. But power in the state’s government largely remains in the hands of Republicans.
content: ATLANTA — For two months, Georgia Republicans have watched their party descend into a morass of betrayal, chaos and blame. A top state election official accused President Trump of fomenting a “civil war” among fellow Republicans as he pressured the governor and the secretary of state to help overturn his electoral defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump’s Lackeys Must Also Be Punished
description: The rule of law has to apply to everyone, including those in power.
content: Never trust politicians. They are craven. It’s an occupational attribute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: He Created the Web. Now He’s Out to Remake the Digital World.
description: Tim Berners-Lee wants to put people in control of their personal data. He has technology and a start-up pursuing that goal. Can he succeed?
content: Three decades ago, Tim Berners-Lee devised simple yet powerful standards for locating, linking and presenting multimedia documents online. He set them free into the world, unleashing the World Wide Web.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Ved Mehta, Celebrated Writer for The New Yorker, Dies at 86
description: He was best known for his 12-volume memoir, which focused on the troubled modern history of his native India and his early struggles with blindness.
content: Ved Mehta, a longtime writer for The New Yorker whose best-known work, spanning a dozen volumes, explored the vast, turbulent history of modern India through the intimate lens of his own autobiography, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Watched People Pass My Booth and Listened to Scraps of Conversation’
description: A unique take on buying art, a sentimental Manhattan walking tour and more reader tales of New York in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
title: The F.B.I. arrests two men who had carried plastic restraints into the Capitol.
description: The F.B.I. arrested two men on Sunday who were photographed in the Senate chamber clad in military-style clothing and holding zip ties, according to a statement issued by the Justice Department.
content: The F.B.I. arrested two men on Sunday who were photographed in the Senate chamber clad in military-style clothing and holding zip ties, according to a statement issued by the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Says ‘No Plans to Pause the Season’ as Virus Cases Increase
description: A game between the Miami Heat and the Boston Celtics was postponed and several teams have been left without key players because of players’ testing positive for the coronavirus and contact tracing.
content: The N.B.A. postponed a game on Sunday night between the Miami Heat and the Boston Celtics when the Heat did not have enough available players because of the league’s coronavirus health and safety protocols. It was the second game of the season postponed after the protocols left a team short-handed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Notable Arrests After the Riot at the Capitol
description: Dozens have been charged in the days since a mob of Trump supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol, disrupting the certification of the 2020 presidential election results.
content: On Wednesday, a mob of Trump supporters, encouraged by President Trump himself, converged on the U.S. Capitol, swept past law enforcement and rampaged through the halls of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Incitement to Riot? What Trump Told Supporters Before Mob Stormed Capitol
description: Here is a closer look at what the president said at a rally of his supporters, which is a central focus of the impeachment case being prepared against him.
content: WASHINGTON — The speech that President Trump delivered to his supporters just before they attacked the Capitol last week is a central focus as House Democrats prepare an article of impeachment against him for inciting the deadly riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Lean into some projects, whether it’s Konbi’s egg salad sandwich or Dorie Greenspan’s Swedish almond cake.
content: Good morning. I like a Sunday spent in the kitchen and if pandemic safety protocols mean I can’t use the day to make a big supper for neighborhood friends and family, the hours can still pay delicious dividends, and for many days to come. Mask up and shop! We’ve got a big agenda this afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Biden’s Pick for Defense Secretary Unlikely to Be in Job on Administration’s First Day
description: The nominee, Lloyd J. Austin III, a retired four-star Army general, must obtain a congressional exemption from a law that bars recent active-duty officers from serving in the top Pentagon job.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is facing an arduous struggle to get his choice for secretary of defense in place by Inauguration Day, a senior national security position that all but one president in modern history has secured by Day 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Luke Broadwater
title: Police Officer Who Responded to Capitol Riot Dies Off Duty
description: Officer Howard Liebengood had been with the Capitol Police since 2005 and assigned to protect the Senate. The cause of his death was not provided.
content: WASHINGTON — Four days after a violent mob stormed the Capitol, overrunning its police force, an officer who was assigned to protect the Senate during the siege died off duty, the Capitol Police announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Teenager Killed After Hand Grenade Bought at an Antique Mall Explodes
description: Officials said that more of the World War II-era grenades, which had been thought to be inactive, may have been sold this summer at an antiques mall in North Carolina.
content: A teenager in Virginia was killed two days before Christmas after a World War II-era hand grenade that was thought to be inactive exploded, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Javier C. Hernández
title: A Year After Wuhan, China Tells a Tale of Triumph (and No Mistakes)
description: The Chinese Communist Party’s efforts to hide its missteps have taken on new urgency as the anniversary of the world’s first Covid-19 lockdown nears.
content: At a museum in Wuhan, China, a sprawling exhibition paints a stirring tale of how the city’s sacrifices in a brutal 76-day lockdown led to triumph over the coronavirus and, ultimately, rebirth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: To Run and Take Notes at the Same Time
description: During a 24-hour race, I tried to interview as many of my fellow runners as possible early on, while we were fresh, excited and coherent.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Davey Alba
title: Amazon, Apple and Google Cut Off Parler, an App That Drew Trump Supporters
description: The companies pulled support for the “free speech” social network, all but killing the service just as many conservatives are seeking alternatives to Facebook and Twitter.
content: Parler, a social network that pitches itself as a “free speech” alternative to Twitter and Facebook, is suffering from whiplash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Mason
title: ‘The Start’
description: A "news poem" in response to last week’s violent melee at the Capitol, written by the state poet of Nebraska, Matt Mason.
content: Matt Mason, the state poet of Nebraska, wrote “The Start,” a poem that responds to last week’s violent melee at the Capitol. It’s the second “news poem” he has written for The New York Times in recent months; the first, called “When Asked What I Am Thankful For,” was part of a collection solicited from state poets laureate across the country at Thanksgiving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Angier
title: How This Spot (in Mozambique) Got Its Leopard
description: Gorongosa National Park, steadily recovering from the ravages of civil war, recently added to its list of resident predators.
content: Late in November, after three grinding years of begging, bartering, form-filling, false starts and blind alleys, and finally through the added pressures of a global pandemic, the wildlife team at Gorongosa National Park in Mozambique at last greeted the arrival of its newest celebrity: a female leopard, 3½ years old, from South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: The Art of the Lie? The Bigger the Better
description: Lying as a political tool is hardly new. But a readiness, even enthusiasm, to be deceived has become a driving force in politics around the world, most recently in the United States.
content: MOSCOW — In a cable to Washington in 1944, George F. Kennan, counselor at the United States Embassy in Stalin’s Moscow, warned of the occult power held by lies, noting that Soviet rule “has proved some strange and disturbing things about human nature.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Garsten
title: Impeach and Convict Trump. Congress Must Defend Itself.
description: Trump’s incitement of a riot is a violation of the separation of powers that threatens the foundation of the Republic.
content: It is tempting to try to run out the clock on the Trump presidency. President Trump has already been impeached once and congressional leaders may assume they still lack the necessary Republican votes to convict and remove him in the Senate. Lawmakers concerned about the possibility for new abuses of power before Jan. 20 have been tempted to settle for urging the president to resign. But more is at stake than what the president might do in the next few days. If Congress declines to impeach and convict the president for his actions on Wednesday, its failure to act will weaken the basic structure of the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Recycle Your Pandemic Habits
description: Starting a new habit is hard. To make it easier, try recycling an old one instead, building on lessons you learned from pandemic living.
content: The following is a review, created for the print edition, of several longer stories that have run this week, called the 7 Day Well Challenge. Below you can find links to the full stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Klein
title: James Comey’s View of Justice — and How It Differs From Donald Trump’s
description: Comey’s “Saving Justice” is a revealing memoir that describes his feelings about Trump and his worries about the nation.
content: SAVING JUSTICETruth, Transparency, and TrustBy James Comey
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: At Elite Medical Centers, Even Workers Who Don’t Qualify Are Vaccinated
description: Administrators and young graduate students have been inoculated at leading research hospitals, contrary to state and federal guidelines.
content: A 20-something who works on computers. A young researcher who studies cancer. Technicians in basic research labs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Let Down by ‘Wonder Woman 1984’? Here are 6 Great Superhero Movies
description: The Wonder Woman sequel received mixed reviews. But there are plenty of excellent and entertaining alternatives to stream, and many that never received the attention they deserve.
content: Last month, Warner Bros. released the coronavirus-delayed “Wonder Woman 1984,” a sequel to the 2017 hit “Wonder Woman.” The action-adventure movie has done relatively well at the box office (in places where theaters are open), even though it’s also available for a limited time on the streaming service HBO Max. But compared with the enthusiastic response to the first “Wonder Woman” movie, the sequel has drawn a mixed reaction, with some critics and comic book fans complaining about the film’s unlikely plot and lengthy running time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Impeachment, Coronavirus, N.F.L. Playoffs: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: The Narcissist in Chief Brings It All Crashing Down
description: An ending as terrible as it was predictable engulfs the president and the country.
content: Our president has never been a very stable man. But I’m trying to think of what threshold of loco he had to clear in order for one of his senior advisers to confide in my colleague Maggie Haberman that Donald J. Trump “lost it” on the day of the insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 11, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Smith
title: 2 New Picture Books Depict the Elusive Hide-and-Seek of Grief
description: Andrew Arnold’s “What’s the Matter, Marlo?” and Matthew Cordell’s “Bear Island” separate the person from the emotions, and model empathy.
content: WHAT’S THE MATTER, MARLO?By Andrew Arnold
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Pence plans to attend Biden’s inauguration.
description: Vice President Mike Pence will attend President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration on Jan. 20, an aide to the vice president said on Saturday, a split with President Trump’s decision not to go.
content: Vice President Mike Pence will attend President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration on Jan. 20, an aide to the vice president said on Saturday, a split with President Trump’s decision not to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Stripped of Twitter, Trump Faces a New Challenge: How to Command Attention
description: Mr. Trump became a celebrity through television, but Twitter had given him a singular outlet for expressing himself as he is, unfiltered by the norms of the presidency.
content: His public persona was a product of television for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: After Unused Vaccines Are Thrown in Trash, Cuomo Loosens Rules
description: Now, employees who interact with the public, including pharmacy cashiers, qualify. It was the second time in two days that the state amended its rules.
content: Across New York State, medical providers in recent weeks had the same story: They had been forced to throw out precious vaccine doses because of difficulties finding patients who matched precisely with the state’s strict vaccination guidelines — and the steep penalties they would face had they made a mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Indonesia Crash: What to Know About the Boeing Plane
description: The 737-500 that crashed near Jakarta was a 26-year-old workhorse without the new technology that plagued the 737 Max.
content: The crash of a plane in Indonesia carrying more than 60 people comes at a difficult time for the aviation giant Boeing, which has seen its reputation battered by years of investigations over deadly crashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Tennis Players Mull Competition or Rest at Start of New Season
description: With the Australian Open looming, the first big decision for 2021 contenders was whether to play in the first tennis tournaments of the year.
content: Figuring out where and how to start the tennis season is usually pretty easy for the world’s top players. They catch a flight to Australia around Christmas, spend a few days getting over the jet lag, then compete for two weeks in warm-up tournaments ahead of the Australian Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Major Technology Companies Join List of Biden Inaugural Donors
description: The inaugural committee did not disclose how much it has raised so far for the event, which is to be scaled down because of the pandemic.
content: Major technology companies like Google and Microsoft, as well as telecommunications giants like Comcast and Verizon, are among the nearly 1,000 people and groups that have donated at least $200 to the committee organizing President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s scaled-back inauguration celebration this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Populist, Prisoner, President: A Convicted Kidnapper Wins Kyrgyzstan Election
description: In a country where presidents’ tenures often end with violent upheavals, Sadyr Japarov emerged victorious in a snap election set off by an uprising last fall.
content: MOSCOW — A populist politician and convicted kidnapper won a landslide victory on Sunday in a snap presidential election in Kyrgyzstan triggered by a popular uprising against the previous government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Najim Rahim
title: Afghan Leaders Sideline Spokesmen in an Escalating Misinformation War
description: The Ghani administration and the Taliban are fighting a public-relations battle, with the government taking more drastic measures to control the flow of information.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — After Ahmad Jawad Hijri saw the wounded children in the hospital and learned of the Afghan airstrike that put them there, killing nine others around their age in northern Afghanistan, he never expected that his response would land him in jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Four days after a riot at the Capitol, the likelihood of the House’s impeaching Trump continues to grow.
description: Momentum for impeaching President Trump a second time was growing rapidly over the weekend among rank-and-file Democrats and some Republicans, setting the stage for a final showdown that would test the boundaries of politics, accountability and the Constitution.
content: Momentum for impeaching President Trump a second time was growing rapidly over the weekend among rank-and-file Democrats and some Republicans, setting the stage for a final showdown that would test the boundaries of politics, accountability and the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Price of Chaos
description: Facebook, Twitter and other businesses banned Trump after he incited a deadly insurrection in Washington.
content: No one should have been surprised by the violence in Washington this past week, but it was stunning nonetheless. Here’s how the business and tech industries are reacting, and what comes next. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dera Menra Sijabat and Richard C. Paddock
title: At Least 12 Dead in 2 Landslides in Indonesia
description: The landslides on the island of Java were set off by heavy rainfall and unstable soil, officials said, and left rescue workers searching for survivors.
content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Two landslides set off by heavy rainfall and unstable soil killed at least 12 people on Java, Indonesia’s most populous island, and left rescue workers searching for survivors, disaster officials said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man With Assault Rifle Charged With Threatening Pelosi, Officials Say
description: The Department of Justice said on Friday that Cleveland Grover Meredith Jr. was one of 13 people who had been charged in federal court after a violent pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol.
content: A man who had an assault rifle was charged with threatening Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, after he traveled to Washington for the pro-Trump rally on Wednesday and sent a text message saying he would put “a bullet in her noggin on Live TV,” the federal authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump has not lowered flags in honor of an officer who died from injuries sustained amid the riot.
description: President Trump has not ordered the flags on federal buildings to fly at half-staff in honor of Brian D. Sicknick, a police officer who was killed after trying to fend off pro-Trump loyalists during the siege at the Capitol on Wednesday.
content: President Trump has not ordered the flags on federal buildings to fly at half-staff in honor of Brian D. Sicknick, a police officer who was killed after trying to fend off pro-Trump loyalists during the siege at the Capitol on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Apple, Google and Amazon kick Parler off their platforms
description: Apple and Google said they would remove Parler from its App Stores. Amazon said it would no longer host Parler on its web hosting service.
content: Apple and Google said they would remove Parler from its App Stores. Amazon said it would no longer host Parler on its web hosting service.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘A Mother and Daughter at the End’
description: The story of the last two white northern rhinos on earth.
content: At first glance, rhinos appear dangerous. But their life mission has always been peaceful: to eat plants and reproduce. Without many predators or any prey, rhinos flourished for millions of years. Humans put an end to that, as we hunted them down and destroyed their habitat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Witness to an Execution: A Chilling Account
